claim: Donald Trump was the most recent U.S. president not selected as Time's Person of the Year.

supporting.text: Donald Trump was the U.S. president before Joe Biden, and Joe Biden was selected as Time's Person of the Year in 2020, making Trump the most recent president not selected.

attacks.text: Donald Trump was the U.S. president before Joe Biden, and Joe Biden was selected as Time's Person of the Year in 2020, making Trump the most recent president not selected.
Time's Person of the Year is not solely based on being the current U.S. president, so the comparison is irrelevant.
Other non-presidents or international figures have been selected, so Trump not being selected doesn't uniquely highlight him.
Trump was featured on Time's cover multiple times, which may be considered comparable recognition.
The U.S. president is often a strong candidate for Time's Person of the Year due to global influence, making the comparison valid.
The claim specifically focuses on U.S. presidents, so non-presidential selections are outside the scope.
Being on the cover is not the same as being named Person of the Year, which is a distinct honor.
Global influence alone doesn't guarantee selection, as Time considers broader impact beyond political office.
Even within U.S. presidents, the selection criteria vary yearly, making direct comparisons unreliable.

supporting.text: Time's Person of the Year selection criteria focus on influence, not just political office, so a president not being selected does not necessarily mean they were overlooked due to recency.

attacks.text: Time's Person of the Year selection criteria focus on influence, not just political office, so a president not being selected does not necessarily mean they were overlooked due to recency.
Presidents inherently hold significant influence due to their position, making their exclusion from Time's Person of the Year notable and potentially indicative of a deliberate oversight.
Time's Person of the Year has frequently selected sitting U.S. presidents, suggesting that Trump's omission is unusual and warrants explanation beyond general selection criteria.
While presidents are influential, Time's selection also considers broader global impact, which may have been overshadowed by other figures during Trump's presidency.
The frequency of presidents being selected varies by era, and recent trends may reflect a shift in Time's editorial focus rather than a specific judgment on Trump.
Even with broader global impact considered, the U.S. president's role is uniquely influential, making Trump's omission more conspicuous compared to other global figures.
Editorial shifts at Time do not fully explain why Trump was omitted, as other recent presidents were still selected despite similar shifts in focus.

supporting.text: Barack Obama was selected as Time's Person of the Year twice (2008, 2012), and Joe Biden was selected in 2020, leaving Trump as the only recent president not selected.

attacks.text: Barack Obama was selected as Time's Person of the Year twice (2008, 2012), and Joe Biden was selected in 2020, leaving Trump as the only recent president not selected.
Time's Person of the Year is not a measure of presidential success or influence, so Trump's exclusion does not reflect on his presidency.
Trump was featured on Time's cover multiple times during his presidency, indicating significant media attention even if not as Person of the Year.
Other recent presidents like George W. Bush were also not selected as Person of the Year, making Trump's case less unique.
While not a direct measure, Time's selection often reflects cultural and political impact, which suggests Trump's exclusion may indicate lesser influence.
Being featured on the cover is not equivalent to the honor of being Person of the Year, which is a distinct recognition.
George W. Bush was selected as Person of the Year in 2000 and 2004, contradicting the claim that he was not selected.
Time's selection criteria are subjective and can be influenced by editorial bias, so it may not accurately reflect a president's true impact.
The distinction between cover features and Person of the Year is arbitrary and does not diminish Trump's media presence or influence.

supporting.text: Time's Person of the Year has occasionally selected non-political figures or groups during presidential terms, which could mean Trump's omission was due to other influential figures rather than his presidency.

attacks.text: Time's Person of the Year has occasionally selected non-political figures or groups during presidential terms, which could mean Trump's omission was due to other influential figures rather than his presidency.
Trump's polarizing presidency and controversies may have influenced Time's decision to avoid selecting him, regardless of other influential figures.
Time's selection criteria prioritize global impact, and Trump's policies may not have been deemed as globally transformative compared to other candidates.
Even polarizing figures have been selected before (e.g., Nixon, Stalin), so controversy alone doesn't explain Trump's omission.
Trump's policies, such as trade wars and Middle East diplomacy, had significant global repercussions, contradicting the claim of lacking global impact.
The context of Nixon's and Stalin's selections was different, as Time's criteria and societal norms have evolved since then.

supporting.text: Donald Trump was featured on Time's cover multiple times, which could imply recognition even if he wasn't formally named Person of the Year.

attacks.text: Donald Trump was featured on Time's cover multiple times, which could imply recognition even if he wasn't formally named Person of the Year.
Being featured on Time's cover does not equate to being selected as Person of the Year, which is a distinct and more prestigious honor.
Time's cover features many controversial figures for negative reasons, which does not necessarily imply recognition or approval.
The frequency of cover appearances can still indicate significant influence or newsworthiness, which aligns with the spirit of the Person of the Year selection.
Even if some cover features are negative, the attention itself underscores Trump's impact on global events, a criterion for Person of the Year.
Significant influence does not automatically warrant Person of the Year, as the title is reserved for those who embody the year's most defining events or movements.
Negative impact or controversy alone is insufficient for Person of the Year, which traditionally celebrates constructive or transformative influence.
